SCENE — A DESOLATED TRACK IN LA VENDEE. — FAMINE IS DISCOVERED STRETCHED ON THE GROUND:  TO HER ENTER FIRE AND SLAUGHTER.
FAMINE.</br>Sisters!  Sisters!  who sent you here?
SLAUGHTER.</br>I will name him in your ear.

FIRE.</br>No!  no!  no!</br>Spirits hear what spirits tell:</br>'Twill make a holiday in hell.</br>No!  no!  no!</br>Myself I nam'd him once below,</br>And all the souls, that damned be,</br>Leap'd up at once in anarchy;</br>Clapp'd their hands and danc'd for glee;</br>They no longer heeded me;</br>But laugh'd to hear Hell's burning rafters</br>Unwillingly re-echo laughters.</br>No!  no!  no!</br>Spirits hear what spirits tell,</br>'Twill make a holiday in hell.
FAMINE.</br>Then sound it not, yet let me know;</br>Darkly hint it — soft and low!
SLAUGHTER.</br>Four letters form his name.</br>And who sent you?
FAMINE.</br>The same!  the same!
SLAUGHTER.</br>He came by stealth and unlock'd my den,</br>And I have drank the blood since then</br>Of thrice ten hundred thousand men.
FIRE AND FAMINE.</br>Who bade you do't?
SLAUGHTER.</br>The same!  the same!</br>Four letters form his name.</br>He let me loose, and cry'd Halloo!</br>To him alone the praise is due.

FAMINE.</br>Thanks, Sisters, thanks!  the men have bled,</br>Their wives and their children faint for bread;</br>I stood in a swampy field of battle,</br>With bones and sculls I made a rattle,</br>To frighten the wolf and the carrion crow,</br>And the homeless dog — but they would not go.</br>So off I flew; for how could I bear</br>To see them gorge their dainty fare.</br>I heard a groan, and a peevish squall,</br>And thro' the chink of a cottage wall,</br>Can you guess what I saw there?
SLAUGHTER AND FIRE.</br>Whisper it, Sister!  in our ear!
FAMINE.</br>A baby beat its dying mother—</br>I had starv'd the one, and was starving the other!
SLAUGHTER AND FIRE.</br>Who bad you do't?
FAMINE.</br>The same!  the same!</br>Four letters form his name.</br>He let me loose, and cry'd Halloo!</br>To him alone the praise is due.

FIRE.</br>Sisters!  I from Ireland came—</br>Hedge and corn-fields all on flame,</br>I triumph'd o'er the setting Sun;</br>And all the while the work was done.</br>And on as I strode with monst'rous strides,</br>I flung back my head, and held my sides;</br>It was so rare a piece of fun,</br>To see the swelter'd cattle run,</br>With uncouth gallop, all the night,</br>Scar'd by the red and noisy light!</br>By the light of his own blazing Cot</br>Was many a naked Rebel shot:</br>The house-stream met the flames, and hiss'd</br>While crash!  fell in the roof, I wist</br>On some of those old bed-rid nurses,</br>That deal in discontent and curses!
SLAUGHTER AND FAMINE.</br>Who bade you do't?
FIRE.</br>The same!  the same!</br>Four letters form his name.</br>He let me loose, and cry'd Halloo!</br>How shall I give him honour due?
ALL.</br>He let us loose, and cry'd halloo!</br>How shall we give him honour due?
FAMINE.</br>Wisdom comes with lack of food,</br>I'll gnaw, I'll gnaw the multitude,</br>Till the cup of rage o'er brim,</br>They shall seize him and his brood.
SLAUGHTER.</br>They shall tear him limb from limb!
FIRE.</br>O thankless Beldames, and untrue,</br>And is this all that you can do</br>For him who did so much for you?
TO SLAUGHTER.</br>For you he turn'd the dust to mud,</br>With his fellow creatures' blood!
TO FAMINE.</br>And hunger scorch'd as many more,</br>To make your cup of joy run o'er.

TO BOTH.</br>Full ninety moons, he by my troth,</br>Hath richly cater'd for you both;</br>And in an hour would you repay,</br>An eight years debt, away!  away!</br>I alone am faithful, I</br>Cling to him everlastingly!</br>
